tn.text: See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]]

tn.ref: Oh, you are beautiful ... eyes are doves
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:15|1:15]].
Goats are often dark in color and when they walk on the mountains their hair would look like the long waves in a woman's hair. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Your teeth are like a flock of newly shorn ewes
tn.text: After sheep have their wool cut off, they are washed and their skin looks very white. This phrase compares the whiteness of the teeth of the woman to the brightness of white sheep wool after their wool has been sheared off. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: a flock of newly shorn ewes
tn.text: AT: "a flock of ewes whose wool people have cut off." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: coming up from the washing place
tn.text: It is implied that the ewes are coming up out of the water. AT: "that are coming up out of the water after people have washed them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Sheep usually give birth to two lambs at one time. These twin lamb usually look like one another. Each of the woman's teeth has a matching tooth on the other side of her mouth. So it is like each tooth has a twin like the lambs. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
None of her teeth have lost their matching tooth on the other side. The woman has not lost any of her teeth.
To have lost a loved one who has died.
The lover continues to praise the woman.

tn.ref: are like a thread of scarlet
tn.text: This phrase compares the color of the woman's lips with scarlet thread. AT: "are a deep red like scarlet thread." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
a dark red color that is very similar to the color of blood
"is beautiful"
Pomegranates are smooth, round, and have a rich red color. AT: "are rosy and round like two halves of a pomegranate." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:04:01|4:1]].
The lover continues to praise the woman.
AT: "neck is long and beautiful like." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"that David built"

Women had necklaces that covered their entire necks with rows of decorations. The lover compares these rows of decorations with the rows of stone on the tower. AT: "that has many rows of stone." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The lover compares the decorations of the woman's necklace with shields hanging on the tower. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"1,000 shields." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"all of the shields belong to mighty warriors"

tn.ref: like two fawns, twins of a gazelle
tn.text: The woman's breasts are beautiful, matching and soft like two baby deer or two baby gazelle. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
the babies of a mother who gave birth to two babies at one time
See how you translated "gazelles" in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:07|2:7]].
"eating plants among the lilies." The beautiful fawns and baby gazelle are even more beautiful when lilies are surrounding them.
The lover continues to praise the woman.

tn.ref: Until the dawn arrives and the shadows flee away
tn.text: See how you translated the line in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:16|2:17]] where the wording is the same as this one.

tn.ref: I will go to the mountain of myrrh and to the hill of frankincense
tn.text: The lover expresses his desire to enjoy the woman's breasts by comparing them with mountains or hills that he likes. Her breasts are round and protrude like mountains or hills. They smell sweet like myrrh and frankincense. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will go to the mountain ... hill of frankincense.
tn.text: These lines repeat the thought in slightly differing ways to emphasize the attractiveness of the lover's breasts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"the mountain made of myrrh" or "the mountain that has myrrh on it"

tn.ref: You are beautiful in every way
tn.text: "Every part of you is beautiful" or "All of you is beautiful"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:09|1:9]].

tn.ref: there is no blemish in you
tn.text: "you have no blemish"
The lover continues to speak to the woman.

tn.ref: Come with me ... dens of leopards
tn.text: The lover wants his bride to come with him away from a wild and dangerous place. This is a metaphor and the couple is not really on these mountains or by these dens. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"away from Lebanon"
the name of a mountain near Damascus (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
the name of a mountain near Amana and Hermon. Some people think that this refers to the same mountain as Hermon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
places where lions and leopards live, like caves or holes in the ground
The lover continues to speak to the woman.
He is saying his affection and love now belong to her. AT: "have captured my love." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The woman is as dear to the lover as his own sister. They are not actually brother and sister. AT: "my dear" or "my darling" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: with just one look at me, with just one jewel of your necklace
tn.text: Both the woman's eyes and her jewelry attract her lover to her.
The lover continues to praise the woman.
"Your love is wonderful"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:04:09|4:9]].

tn.ref: How much better is your love than wine
tn.text: These lines repeat the same idea in different words for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: How much better is your love than wine
tn.text: "Your love is much better than wine." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:01|1:2]].

tn.ref: the fragrance of your perfume than any spice
tn.text: "the smell of your oils is better than the smell of any spice." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
See how you translated these words in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:01|1:3]].
dried plants or seeds that have a good smell or taste
These lines repeat the same idea in different words for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Your lips, my bride, drip honey
tn.text: The lover thinks that the woman's kisses are sweet like honey; or, because the words that she speaks are sweet like honey. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: honey and milk are under your tongue
tn.text: The lover thinks that the woman's kisses are sweet like milk and honey; or, that she speaks words that are as sweet as milk and honey. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the fragrance of your garments is like the fragrance of Lebanon
tn.text: "the smell of your clothes is like the smell of Lebanon." Many cedar trees grew in Lebanon. Cedar trees smell very good, so Lebanon would have smelled sweet and fresh.
The lover continues to praise the woman.
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:04:09|4:9]].

"is a garden that is locked." The lover compares the woman with a locked garden because she belongs only to him and only he can enjoy her. He might also be saying that she is still a virgin whom he has not yet enjoyed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

The lover compares the woman with a sealed spring for the same reasons that he compared her with a locked garden. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
The lover describes how wonderful the woman is by describing her as a garden full of wonderful things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a place where many trees grow together
"with the best kinds of fruits"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:12|1:14]].
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:12|1:12]].
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:04:12|4:14]]
a spice that comes from the dried parts from the yellow thread in the center of a certain flower.
This is a reed with a pleasant smell that people used to make anointing oil.
a spice made from the bark of a tree that people used for cooking
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:12|1:13]].
a type of large plant that had a very sweet smell
"all the best spices"
The lover continues to praise the woman.
"You are a spring in a garden." The lover describes how wonderful by comparing her with good water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
water that is good to drink
Because Lebanon had mountains covered with trees, the streams from Lebanon would be clean and cool.

tn.ref: Awake ... may give off their fragrance
tn.text: The woman speaks to the north wind and the south wind as though they were people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"Start moving"
The woman refers to her body by speaking about it as a garden. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"send out their good smells"
The woman is inviting her lover to enjoy her as his wife. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"wonderful fruit"
